column1: Pulmonary valve stenosis is a heart valve disorder that involves the pulmonary valve.
This is the valve separating the right ventricle (one of the chambers in the heart) and the pulmonary artery.
The pulmonary artery carries oxygen-poor blood to the lungs.

When the valve narrowing (stenosis) is moderate to severe, the symptoms include: - Abdominal distention - Bluish color to the skin (cyanosis) in some patients - Chest pain - Fainting - Fatigue - Poor weight gain or failure to thrive in infants with a severe blockage - Shortness of breath - Sudden death Symptoms may get worse with exercise or activity.
The health care provider may hear a heart murmur when listening to the heart using a stethoscope.

Tests used to diagnose pulmonary stenosis may include: - Cardiac catheterization - Chest x-ray - ECG - Echocardiogram - MRI of the heart The health care provider will grade the severity of the valve stenosis to plan treatment.
- This procedure is done through an artery in the groin.
People with mild disease rarely get worse.
Call your health care provider if: - You have symptoms of pulmonary valve stenosis.
